info.author: Caoxiang ZHU
info.description:
FortranNamelist
======

FortranNamelist is a standalone python package/class for parsing Fortran/IDL namelist.
It is modified from [OMFIT namelist](https://omfit.io/code.html#module-classes.namelist).

Features:
  - Support Fortran indexing
  - Support multi-dimensional arrays
  - Retain comments

NOTE: I haven't tested/cleaned all the functions. Please use at your own warranty.

Install
=======

You can install the package using `pip`.

```
pip install FortranNamelist
```

Or from `TestPypi` using

```
pip install --index-url https://test.pypi.org/simple/ FortranNamelist
```

You can also install it by cloning the source code.

```
git clone https://github.com/zhucaoxiang/namelist.git
cd namelist
python setup.py install
```

Use
=======

Here is some simple examples of using the package.
There are more functions and you can have a view in the source code.

## Parse Fortran namelist

By default, it will use Fortran indexing convention.
There is not special meaning for negative index.

```python
import FortranNamelist.namelist as nml
ranged_nl = nml.NamelistFile(input_string='''
                             &test
                                 entry(-2, -2) = -10
                                 entry(1,1) = 1
                                 entry(2,1:2) = 1, 2
                                 entry(3,1) = 1
                                 entry(3,2) = 2
                                 entry(3,3) = 3
                                 entry(4,1) = 4
                                 entry(5,1:2) = 1, 2
                                 entry(6:7,1) = 6, 7
                             /
                             ''')
print(ranged_nl['test']['entry'][3,1]==1)
print(ranged_nl['test']['entry'][-2,-2]==-10)
```

You can also read namelist from file.
```python
ranged_nl = nml.NamelistFile('path-to-file')
```
## Write namelist to file

You can write the namelist to a file by using

```python
ranged_nl.save() # default saved to ranged_nl.filename
```

or using 

```python
ranged_nl.saveas('path-to-new-file')
```

## Use python indexing

You can also switch to python indexing convention

```python
with nml.python_environment(ranged_nl) :
    print(ranged_nl['test']['entry'][0,0])
    print(ranged_nl['test']['entry'][-1,-1])
```

Contact
=======

You can report bugs on `GitHub issues` and propose improvements using `pull request`.
For more information, please contact Dr. Caoxiang ZHU (caoxiangzhu[at]gmail.com).

info.html_description:
FortranNamelist

FortranNamelist is a standalone python package/class for parsing Fortran/IDL namelist. It is modified from OMFIT namelist.

Features:

  • Support Fortran indexing
  • Support multi-dimensional arrays
  • Retain comments

NOTE: I haven't tested/cleaned all the functions. Please use at your own warranty.

Install

You can install the package using pip.

pip install FortranNamelist

Or from TestPypi using

pip install --index-url https://test.pypi.org/simple/ FortranNamelist

You can also install it by cloning the source code.

git clone https://github.com/zhucaoxiang/namelist.git
cd namelist
python setup.py install

Use

Here is some simple examples of using the package. There are more functions and you can have a view in the source code.

Parse Fortran namelist

By default, it will use Fortran indexing convention. There is not special meaning for negative index.

import FortranNamelist.namelist as nml

                             &test
                                 entry(-2, -2) = -10
                                 entry(1,1) = 1
                                 entry(2,1:2) = 1, 2
                                 entry(3,1) = 1
                                 entry(3,2) = 2
                                 entry(3,3) = 3
                                 entry(4,1) = 4
                                 entry(5,1:2) = 1, 2
                                 entry(6:7,1) = 6, 7
                             /
                             ''')
print(ranged_nl['test']['entry'][3,1]==1)
print(ranged_nl['test']['entry'][-2,-2]==-10)

You can also read namelist from file.

You can write the namelist to a file by using

or using

Use python indexing

You can also switch to python indexing convention

with nml.python_environment(ranged_nl) :
    print(ranged_nl['test']['entry'][0,0])
    print(ranged_nl['test']['entry'][-1,-1])

You can report bugs on GitHub issues and propose improvements using pull request. For more information, please contact Dr. Caoxiang ZHU (caoxiangzhu[at]gmail.com).
